1.21.text:
The Bee-Man of Orn
by Frank R. Stockton

8.45.text:
In the ancient country of Orn, there lived
an old man who was called the Bee-man, because

14.27.text:
his whole time was spent in the company of
bees.

17.54.text:
He lived in a small hut, which was nothing
more than an immense bee-hive, for these little

22.79.text:
creatures had built their honeycombs in every
corner of the one room it contained, on the

27.87.text:
shelves, under the little table, all about
the rough bench on which the old man sat,

32.72.text:
and even about the head-board and along the
sides of his low bed.

37.39.text:
All day the air of the room was thick with
buzzing insects, but this did not interfere

41.75.text:
in any way with the old Bee-man, who walked
in among them, ate his meals, and went to

47.16.text:
sleep, without the slightest fear of being
stung.

50.31.text:
He had lived with the bees so long, they had
become so accustomed to him, and his skin

55.22.text:
was so tough and hard, that the bees no more
thought of stinging him than they would of

60.20.text: stinging a tree or a stone.

62.60.text:
A swarm of bees had made their hive in a pocket
of his old leathern doublet; and when he put

68.18.text:
on this coat to take one of his long walks
in the forest in search of wild bees' nests,

73.48.text:
he was very glad to have this hive with him,
for, if he did not find any wild honey, he

78.81.text:
would put his hand in his pocket and take
out a piece of a comb for a luncheon.

83.78.text:
The bees in his pocket worked very industriously,
and he was always certain of having something

88.64.text: to eat with him wherever he went.

91.23.text:
He lived principally upon honey; and when
he needed bread or meat, he carried some fine

96.29.text:
combs to a village not far away and bartered
them for other food.

101.39.text: He was ugly, untidy, shrivelled, and brown.

105.34.text:
He was poor, and the bees seemed to be his
only friends.

109.00.text:
But, for all that, he was happy and contented;
he had all the honey he wanted, and his bees,

114.93.text:
whom he considered the best company in the
world, were as friendly and sociable as they

118.62.text:
could be, and seemed to increase in number
every day.

123.10.text:
One day, there stopped at the hut of the Bee-man
a Junior Sorcerer.

128.31.text:
This young person, who was a student of magic,
necromancy, and the kindred arts, was much

133.06.text:
interested in the Bee-man, whom he had frequently
noticed in his wanderings, and he considered

138.03.text: him an admirable subject for study.

141.11.text:
He had got a great deal of useful practice
by endeavoring to find out, by the various

145.52.text:
rules and laws of sorcery, exactly why the
old Bee-man did not happen to be something

150.98.text:
that he was not, and why he was what he happened
to be.

155.52.text:
He had studied a long time at this matter,
and had found out something.

159.57.text:
"Do you know," he said, when the Bee-man came
out of his hut, "that you have been transformed?"

165.58.text:
"What do you mean by that?" said the other,
much surprised.

170.40.text:
"You have surely heard of animals and human
beings who have been magically transformed

177.82.text:
"Yes, I have heard of these things," said
the Bee-man; "but what have I been transformed

184.27.text:
"That is more than I know," said the Junior
Sorcerer.

187.85.text:
"But one thing is certain—you ought to be
changed back.

192.12.text:
If you will find out what you have been transformed
from, I will see that you are made all right

198.11.text:
Nothing would please me better than to attend
to such a case."

201.36.text:
And, having a great many things to study and
investigate, the Junior Sorcerer went his

207.54.text:
This information greatly disturbed the mind
of the Bee-man.

211.20.text:
If he had been changed from something else,
he ought to be that other thing, whatever

217.02.text: He ran after the young man, and overtook him.

219.69.text:
"If you know, kind sir," he said, "that I
have been transformed, you surely are able

224.38.text: to tell me what it is that I was."

227.25.text:
"No," said the Junior Sorcerer, "my studies
have not proceeded far enough for that.

233.03.text:
When I become a senior I can tell you all
about it.

235.87.text:
But, in the meantime, it will be well for
you to try to discover for yourself your original

240.42.text:
form, and when you have done that, I will
get some of the learned masters of my art

247.20.text:
It will be easy enough to do that, but you
could not expect them to take the time and

251.32.text: trouble to find out what it was."

253.88.text:
And, with these words, he hurried away, and
was soon lost to view.

259.72.text:
Greatly disquieted, the Bee-man retraced his
steps, and went to his hut.

264.14.text:
Never before had he heard any thing which
had so troubled him.

267.92.text:
"I wonder what I was transformed from?" he
thought, seating himself on his rough bench.

273.12.text:
"Could it have been a giant, or a powerful
prince, or some gorgeous being whom the magicians

278.86.text: or the fairies wished to punish?

281.54.text:
It may be that I was a dog or a horse, or
perhaps a fiery dragon or a horrid snake.

288.30.text: I hope it was not one of these.

290.23.text:
But, whatever it was, every one has certainly
a right to his original form, and I am resolved

297.41.text:
I will start early to-morrow morning, and
I am sorry now that I have not more pockets

301.54.text:
to my old doublet, so that I might carry more
bees and more honey for my journey."

307.00.text:
He spent the rest of the day in making a hive
of twigs and straw, and, having transferred

312.27.text:
to this a number of honey-combs and a colony
of bees which had just swarmed, he rose before

317.25.text:
sunrise the next day, and having put on his
leathern doublet, and having bound his new

322.37.text:
hive to his back, he set forth on his quest;
the bees who were to accompany him buzzing

330.21.text:
As the Bee-man passed through the little village
the people greatly wondered at his queer appearance,

335.87.text: with the hive upon his back.

337.92.text:
"The Bee-man is going on a long expedition
this time," they said; but no one imagined

343.11.text: the strange business on which he was bent.

346.19.text:
About noon he sat down under a tree, near
a beautiful meadow covered with blossoms,

352.17.text:
Then he untied his hive and stretched himself
out on the grass to rest.

356.87.text:
As he gazed upon his bees hovering about him,
some going out to the blossoms in the sunshine,

362.16.text:
and some returning laden with the sweet pollen,
he said to himself, "They know just what they

367.85.text: have to do, and they do it; but alas for me!

371.41.text: I know not what I may have to do.

374.03.text:
And yet, whatever it may be, I am determined
to do it.

377.70.text:
In some way or other I will find out what
was my original form, and then I will have

385.11.text:
And now the thought came to him that perhaps
his original form might have been something

392.64.text: "But it does not matter," he said sturdily.

395.44.text: "Whatever I was that shall I be again.

398.38.text:
It is not right for any one to retain a form
which does not properly belong to him.

403.16.text:
I have no doubt I shall discover my original
form in the same way that I find the trees

407.73.text: in which the wild bees hive.

410.61.text:
When I first catch sight of a bee-tree I am
drawn towards it, I know not how.

416.37.text:
Something says to me: 'That is what you are
looking for.'

419.57.text:
In the same way I believe that I shall find
my original form.

423.57.text: When I see it, I shall be drawn towards it.

426.42.text: Something will say to me: 'That is it.'"

429.89.text:
When the Bee-man was rested he started off
again, and in about an hour he entered a fair

436.32.text:
Around him were beautiful lawns, grand trees,
and lovely gardens; while at a little distance

441.81.text:
stood the stately palace of the Lord of the
Domain.

445.40.text:
Richly dressed people were walking about or
sitting in the shade of the trees and arbors;

451.12.text:
splendidly caparisoned horses were waiting
for their riders; and everywhere were seen

458.26.text:
"I think," said the Bee-man to himself, "that
I should like to stop here for a time.

464.43.text:
If it should happen that I was originally
like any of these happy creatures it would

470.13.text:
He untied his hive, and hid it behind some
bushes, and taking off his old doublet, laid

476.28.text:
It would not do to have his bees flying about
him if he wished to go among the inhabitants

483.10.text:
For two days the Bee-man wandered about the
palace and its grounds, avoiding notice as

487.37.text: much as possible, but looking at every thing.

490.86.text:
He saw handsome men and lovely ladies; the
finest horses, dogs, and cattle that were

496.16.text:
ever known; beautiful birds in cages, and
fishes in crystal globes, and it seemed to

502.05.text:
him that the best of all living things were
here collected.

506.72.text:
At the close of the second day, the Bee-man
said to himself: "There is one being here

511.46.text:
toward whom I feel very much drawn, and that
is the Lord of the Domain.

516.79.text:
I cannot feel certain that I was once like
him, but it would be a very fine thing if

521.60.text:
it were so; and it seems impossible for me
to be drawn toward any other being in the

526.21.text:
domain when I look upon him, so handsome,
rich, and powerful.

531.26.text:
But I must observe him more closely, and feel
more sure of the matter, before applying to

535.78.text:
the sorcerers to change me back into a lord
of a fair domain."

540.87.text:
The next morning, the Bee-man saw the Lord
of the Domain walking in his gardens.

545.65.text:
He slipped along the shady paths, and followed
him so as to observe him closely, and find

550.50.text:
out if he were really drawn toward this noble
and handsome being.

555.22.text:
The Lord of the Domain walked on for some
time, not noticing that the Bee-man was behind

561.08.text:
But suddenly turning, he saw the little old
man.

563.15.text:
"What are you doing here, you vile beggar?"
he cried; and he gave him a kick that sent

568.91.text:
him into some bushes that grew by the side
of the path.

572.52.text:
The Bee-man scrambled to his feet, and ran
as fast as he could to the place where he

576.21.text: had hidden his hive and his old doublet.

578.78.text:
"If I am certain of any thing," he thought,
"it is that I was never a person who would

587.00.text:
I was transformed from nothing that I see
here."

590.63.text:
He now travelled for a day or two longer,
and then he came to a great black mountain,

595.94.text:
near the bottom of which was an opening like
the mouth of a cave.

600.10.text:
This mountain he had heard was filled with
caverns and under-ground passages, which were

604.28.text:
the abodes of dragons, evil spirits, horrid
creatures of all kinds.

608.93.text:
"Ah me!" said the Bee-man with a sigh, "I
suppose I ought to visit this place.

614.81.text:
If I am going to do this thing properly, I
should look on all sides of the subject, and

619.45.text:
I may have been one of those horrid creatures
myself."

623.75.text:
Thereupon he went to the mountain, and as
he approached the opening of the passage which

627.43.text:
led into its inmost recesses he saw, sitting
upon the ground, and leaning his back against

635.61.text:
"Good-day," said this individual when he saw
the Bee-man.

641.25.text:
"Yes," said the Bee-man, "that is what I intend
to do."

645.40.text:
"Then," said the Languid Youth, slowly rising
to his feet, "I think I will go with you.

651.32.text:
I was told that if I went in there I should
get my energies toned up, and they need it

655.83.text:
very much; but I did not feel equal to entering
by myself, and I thought I would wait until

663.12.text:
I am very glad to see you, and we will go
in together."

667.22.text:
So the two went into the cave, and they had
proceeded but a short distance when they met

671.61.text:
a very little creature, whom it was easy to
recognize as a Very Imp.

676.89.text:
He was about two feet high, and resembled
in color a freshly polished pair of boots.

682.20.text:
He was extremely lively and active, and came
bounding toward them.

686.22.text:
"What did you two people come here for?" he
asked.

689.58.text:
"I came," said the Languid Youth, "to have
my energies toned up."

694.10.text:
"You have come to the right place," said the
Very Imp.

698.80.text: And what does that old Bee-man want?"

701.08.text:
"He has been transformed from something, and
wants to find out what it is.

705.39.text:
He thinks he may have been one of the things
in here."

707.91.text:
"I should not wonder if that were so," said
the Very Imp, rolling his head on one side,

713.74.text: and eying the Bee-man with a critical gaze.

716.28.text:
"All right," said the Very Imp; "he can go
around, and pick out his previous existence.

721.49.text:
We have here all sorts of vile creepers, crawlers,
hissers, and snorters.

726.16.text:
I suppose he thinks any thing will be better
than a Bee-man."

729.14.text:
"It is not because I want to be better than
I am," said the Bee-man, "that I started out

735.97.text:
I have simply an honest desire to become what
I originally was."

739.35.text: "Oh! that is it, is it?" said the other.

742.52.text:
"There is an idiotic moon-calf here with a
clam head, which must be just like what you

751.27.text:
"You have not the least idea what an honest
purpose is.

754.80.text: I shall go about, and see for myself."

756.76.text:
"Go ahead," said the Very Imp, "and I will
attend to this fellow who wants to be toned

763.14.text: So saying he joined the Languid Youth.

765.69.text:
"Look here," said that individual, regarding
him with interest, "do you black and shine

772.45.text: "No," said the other, "it is water-proof varnish.

775.40.text: You want to be invigorated, don't you?

777.40.text: Well, I will tell you a splendid way to begin.

779.68.text:
You see that Bee-man has put down his hive
and his coat with the bees in it.

784.04.text:
Just wait till he gets out of sight, and then
catch a lot of those bees, and squeeze them

789.20.text:
If you spread them on a sticky rag, and make
a plaster, and put it on the small of your

793.39.text:
back, it will invigorate you like every thing,
especially if some of the bees are not quite

799.57.text:
"Yes," said the Languid Youth, looking at
him with his mild eyes, "but if I had energy

805.43.text: enough to catch a bee I would be satisfied.

808.81.text: Suppose you catch a lot for me."

810.80.text: "The subject is changed," said the Very Imp.

813.62.text:
"We are now about to visit the spacious chamber
of the King of the Snap-dragons."

817.45.text: "That is a flower," said the Languid Youth.

821.10.text:
"You will find him a gay old blossom," said
the other.

824.58.text:
"When he has chased you round his room, and
has blown sparks at you, and has snorted and

829.19.text:
howled, and cracked his tail, and snapped
his jaws like a pair of anvils, your energies

834.09.text:
will be toned up higher than ever before in
your life."

837.38.text:
"No doubt of it," said the Languid Youth;
"but I think I will begin with something a

843.84.text:
"Well then," said other, "there is a flat-tailed
Demon of the Gorge in here.

850.34.text:
He is generally asleep, and, if you say so,
you can slip into the farthest corner of his

854.44.text:
cave, and I'll solder his tail to the opposite
wall.

858.08.text:
Then he will rage and roar, but he can't get
at you, for he doesn't reach all the way across

862.97.text: his cave; I have measured him.

865.09.text:
It will tone you up wonderfully to sit there
and watch him."

868.02.text:
"Very likely," said the Languid Youth; "but
I would rather stay outside and let you go

875.49.text:
The performance in that way will be more interesting
to me."

879.06.text:
"You are dreadfully hard to please," said
the Very Imp.

883.55.text:
"I have offered them to you loose, and I have
offered them fastened to a wall, and now the

888.73.text:
best thing I can do is to give you a chance
at one of them that can't move at all.

893.94.text: It is the Ghastly Griffin and is enchanted.

896.91.text:
He can't stir so much as the tip of his whiskers
for a thousand years.

901.02.text:
You can go to his cave and examine him just
as if he were stuffed, and then you can sit

905.31.text:
on his back and think how it would be if you
should live to be a thousand years old, and

909.72.text: he should wake up while you are sitting there.

912.62.text:
It would be easy to imagine a lot of horrible
things he would do to you when you look at

916.89.text:
his open mouth with its awful fangs, his dreadful
claws, and his horrible wings all covered

923.26.text:
"I think that might suit me," said the Languid
Youth.

927.62.text:
"I would much rather imagine the exercises
of these monsters than to see them really

933.41.text:
"Come on, then," said the Very Imp, and he
led the way to the cave of the Ghastly Griffin.

940.17.text:
The Bee-man went by himself through a great
part of the mountain, and looked into many

944.49.text:
of its gloomy caves and recesses, recoiling
in horror from most of the dreadful monsters

951.84.text:
While he was wandering about, an awful roar
was heard resounding through the passages

956.09.text:
of the mountain, and soon there came flapping
along an enormous dragon, with body black

961.34.text: as night, and wings and tail of fiery red.

964.92.text: In his great fore-claws he bore a little baby.

971.30.text:
"He is taking that little creature to his
cave to devour it."

975.73.text:
He saw the dragon enter a cave not far away,
and following looked in.

980.13.text:
The dragon was crouched upon the ground with
the little baby lying before him.

984.04.text:
It did not seem to be hurt, but was frightened
and crying.

988.26.text:
The monster was looking upon it with delight,
as if he intended to make a dainty meal of

992.46.text:
it as soon as his appetite should be a little
stronger.

995.60.text: "It is too bad!" thought the Bee-man.

1000.44.text:
And turning around, he ran away as fast as
he could.

1004.37.text:
He ran through various passages until he came
to the spot where he had left his bee-hive.

1009.69.text:
Picking it up, he hurried back, carrying the
hive in his two hands before him.

1014.14.text:
When he reached the cave of the dragon, he
looked in and saw the monster still crouched

1020.30.text:
Without a moment's hesitation, the Bee-man
rushed into the cave and threw his hive straight

1023.95.text: into the face of the dragon.

1025.95.text:
The bees, enraged by the shock, rushed out
in an angry crowd and immediately fell upon

1030.82.text: the head, mouth, eyes, and nose of the dragon.

1034.60.text:
The great monster, astounded by this sudden
attack, and driven almost wild by the numberless

1039.18.text:
stings of the bees, sprang back to the farthest
portion of his cave, still followed by his

1044.28.text:
relentless enemies, at whom he flapped wildly
with his great wings and struck with his paws.

1050.59.text:
While the dragon was thus engaged with the
bees, the Bee-man rushed forward, and, seizing

1057.37.text:
He did not stop to pick up his doublet, but
kept on until he reached the entrance of the

1063.34.text:
There he saw the Very Imp hopping along on
one leg, and rubbing his back and shoulders

1068.08.text:
with his hands, and stopped to inquire what
was the matter, and what had become of the

1073.87.text:
"He is no kind of a fellow," said the Very
Imp.

1079.62.text:
I took him up to the Ghastly Griffin, and
told him the thing was enchanted, and that

1083.97.text:
he might sit on its back and think about what
it could do if it was awake; and when he came

1089.06.text:
near it the wretched creature opened its eyes,
and raised its head, and then you ought to

1093.55.text: have seen how mad that simpleton was.

1096.50.text:
He made a dash at me and seized me by the
ears; he kicked and beat me till I can scarcely

1103.27.text:
"His energies must have been toned up a good
deal," said the Bee-man.

1108.83.text: I should say so!" cried the other.

1110.78.text:
"I raised a howl, and a Scissor-jawed Clipper
came out of his hole, and got after him; but

1115.43.text:
that lazy fool ran so fast that he could not
be caught."

1119.70.text:
The Bee-man now ran on and soon overtook the
Languid Youth.

1124.14.text:
"You need not be in a hurry now," said the
latter, "for the rules of this institution

1128.48.text:
don't allow the creatures inside to come out
of this opening, or to hang around it.

1133.45.text: If they did, they would frighten away visitors.

1135.62.text:
They go in and out of holes in the upper part
of the mountain."

1139.87.text: The two proceeded on their way.

1141.81.text:
"What are you going to do with that baby?"
said the Languid Youth.

1146.27.text:
"I shall carry it along with me," said the
Bee-man, "as I go on with my search, and perhaps

1153.48.text:
If I do not, I shall give it to somebody in
that little village yonder.

1157.10.text:
Any thing would be better than leaving it
to be devoured by that horrid dragon."

1162.74.text:
I feel quite strong enough now to carry a
baby."

1165.71.text:
"Thank you," said the Bee-man, "but I can
take it myself.

1169.09.text:
I like to carry something, and I have now
neither my hive nor my doublet."

1173.56.text:
"It is very well that you had to leave them
behind," said the Youth, "for the bees would

1180.55.text: "My bees never sting babies," said the other.

1184.27.text:
"They probably never had a chance," remarked
his companion.

1188.38.text:
They soon entered the village, and after walking
a short distance the youth exclaimed: "Do

1192.92.text:
you see that woman over there sitting at the
door of her house?

1196.34.text:
She has beautiful hair and she is tearing
it all to pieces.

1199.65.text: She should not be allowed to do that."

1205.80.text:
"Perhaps she is the mother of this child,"
said the Youth, "and if you give it to her

1211.15.text: she will no longer think of tearing her hair."

1213.95.text:
"But," said the Bee-man, "you don't really
think this is her child?"

1218.50.text: "Suppose you go over and see," said the other.

1222.39.text:
The Bee-man hesitated a moment, and then he
walked toward the woman.

1226.63.text:
Hearing him coming, she raised her head, and
when she saw the child she rushed towards

1230.64.text:
it, snatched it into her arms, and screaming
with joy she covered it with kisses.

1235.24.text:
Then with happy tears she begged to know the
story of the rescue of her child, whom she

1239.48.text:
never expected to see again; and she loaded
the Bee-man with thanks and blessings.

1245.10.text:
The friends and neighbors gathered around
and there was great rejoicing.

1249.01.text:
The mother urged the Bee-man and the Youth
to stay with her, and rest and refresh themselves,

1253.78.text:
which they were glad to do as they were tired
and hungry.

1257.14.text:
They remained at the cottage all night, and
in the afternoon of the next day the Bee-man

1261.50.text:
said to the Youth: "It may seem an odd thing
to you, but never in all my life have I felt

1267.21.text:
myself drawn towards any living being as I
am drawn towards this baby.

1271.96.text:
Therefore I believe that I have been transformed
from a baby."

1278.50.text: "It is my opinion that you have hit the truth.

1281.66.text:
And now would you like to be changed back
to your original form?"

1284.81.text:
"Indeed I would!" said the Bee-man, "I have
the strongest yearning to be what I originally

1291.79.text:
The Youth, who had now lost every trace of
languid feeling, took a great interest in

1296.53.text:
the matter, and early the next morning started
off to inform the Junior Sorcerer that the

1300.89.text:
Bee-man had discovered what he had been transformed
from, and desired to be changed back to it.

1306.71.text:
The Junior Sorcerer and his learned Masters
were filled with enthusiasm when they heard

1311.04.text:
this report, and they at once set out for
the mother's cottage.

1315.37.text:
And there by magic arts the Bee-man was changed
back into a baby.

1319.92.text:
The mother was so grateful for what the Bee-man
had done for her that she agreed to take charge

1324.28.text: of this baby, and to bring it up as her own.

1326.99.text:
"It will be a grand thing for him," said the
Junior Sorcerer, "and I am glad that I studied

1333.19.text:
He will now have a fresh start in life, and
will have a chance to become something better

1336.92.text:
than a miserable old man living in a wretched
hut with no friends or companions but buzzing

1343.90.text:
The Junior Sorcerer and his Masters then returned
to their homes, happy in the success of their

1348.92.text:
great performance; and the Youth went back
to his home anxious to begin a life of activity

1356.18.text:
Years and years afterward, when the Junior
Sorcerer had become a Senior and was very

1361.01.text:
old indeed, he passed through the country
of Orn, and noticed a small hut about which

1368.64.text:
He approached it, and looking in at the door
he saw an old man in a leathern doublet, sitting

1375.27.text:
By his magic art he knew this was the baby
which had been transformed from the Bee-man.

1380.48.text:
"Upon my word!" exclaimed the Sorcerer, "He
has grown into the same thing again!"

1387.81.text:
End of The Bee-Man Of Orn
by Frank R. Stockton
